Dear Ron

Thank you for posting a photograph of your beautiful, papered Nam=
ban 
tsuba.  At 84 cms in width it is unusually large for the group - only =

some 3 per cent measure that or more, and the largest one I have seen 
was=
 93 cms.  It is also unusual in that it has two contemporaneous 
ryo-hitsu,=
 and that these are both hangetsu-gata.  Does the smaller 
one have sekigan=
e?

The iron appears to be good, although the extensive carving on these 
t=
subas meant that the iron was never of very good quality.  The 
carving of =
the undercut karakusa and the surface chisel-work are 
sharp and excellent.=
  The plain, squared rim; the absence of OTT gold 
overlay; the conventiona=
lly shaped seppa-dai and ryo-hitsu; and the 
asymmetrical design all combin=
e to  impart a dignity that is seldom 
associated with tsuba of this group.=


This is a beautiful tsuba, and well-deserving of its tokubetsu hozon 
sta=
tus.  I am hesitant to give a firm time period.  On the one hand, 
because =
of the introduction of better metal-working tools, those 
Namban tsuba of a=
 later period are generally the more skillfully 
made.  Conversely, those w=
ith conventional seppa-dai were often 
earlier.  I imagine that the kanteis=
ho says 'Edo period'?  Shall we 
say mid-late C18? 

Regards, John L.

P.S.=
   I hope that you enjoy the book.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "R=
on Hartmann" <swords@...> 
wrote:
>
> Dear John, others - 
> 
> I've posted=
 a photo of the interesting namban tsuba that John had 
referred to earlier=
. The motif consists of dragons and catfish, a 
shrine (with gold jewel pea=
k), breaking waves and vines (?) in 
sukashi work. This large tsuba (84mm r=
nd. x 4mm thick) has Tokubetsu 
Hozon certificate. The poster is in Yahoo p=
hotos: 
http://tinyurl.com/yxt45h
> in a file named: Ron STL  Perhaps John =
wishes to elaborate on this 
tsuba a bit more? 
> 
> John, I've just receiv=
ed my copy of your book, "The Namban Group of 
Japanese Sword Guards; Aa Re=
appraisal" and I'm looking forward to 
digesting your research findings whi=
ch make up this publication. 
Interesting!
> 
> Ron
> STL

>   Dear Patrick
> 
>   Yes indeed - one=
 of the Namban group and probably made by a 
casting 
>   process in the ea=
rly-mid C19. This group is characterised by its 
>   openwork and undercutt=
ing; the common presence of affronted 
dragons 
>   with the tama jewel; an=
d the atypically shaped seppa-dai. All of 
>   these are present on your ts=
uba.
> 
>   I would have expected a tsuba of this type to be of iron, but 
=
some 
>   were cast in bronze. Interestingly these are unexpectedly 
attrac=
ted 
>   by a magnet, but the admixture of up to 30% of iron to bronze in 
=
>   order to reduce the cost of the expensive alloy was not unknown. 
>   A=
lso, iron was a common inclusion in naturally occurring copper 
ore 
> 
>  =
 Regards, John L.
>
